concern:
I am currently working part time at a Sams Club which they schedule me 20-30 hrs a week. I told them I can’t work 2 days specifically since those are the days I have class in community college. This is my second year in but feels like first since I completely bombed my first 2 semesters and I’m on probation now with no financial aid. Thankfully my parents are willing to help to an extent since they don’t have a lot of money either. 

I’m planning to take 4 courses this coming semester, 12 credits. 2 of them are replacement classes since I failed them before. 

Basically what I’m asking is working too much and taking 4 courses at a time rough? I prob know the answer since I’m asking myself this but I wanna know other opinions/options. I want to speed up my graduation process since I’m a transfer or at least trying to transfer but I want to finish community first with an associates

dialogue_total.statement: Hello there! What's on your mind today? I'm all ears and ready to listen.

I'm really worried about balancing my parttime job with my college classes this semester, especially since I'm on academic probation and trying to push through quickly. I want to figure out how to manage my time better so I can succeed without burning out.

It sounds like you've got a lot on your plate! Balancing work and school can be tough, especially when you're on academic probation. It's great that you're thinking about time management strategies to help you succeed without burning out. What have you tried so far that's worked, or hasn't worked?

I've tried adjusting my work schedule to avoid conflicts with my classes, which has helped a little with attendance, but it hasn't prevented me from feeling overwhelmed and falling behind in my studies like before. Overall, I'm struggling to find a sustainable routine that lets me keep up with both without risking burnout again.

It's clear that you're committed to finding a solution that works for you, and that's awesome! It's good that you've already taken steps to adjust your work schedule. But it sounds like there's still more to figure out to find that sustainable routine. Have you thought about breaking down your tasks into smaller chunks, or setting aside specific times for studying and work?

I've tried breaking down my tasks into smaller chunks before, but I often end up rushing through them because of my packed schedule with work and classes, which makes it hard to stick to. Setting aside specific times for studying sounds promising, though I'm worried it might conflict with my unpredictable work hours and lead to more stress.

It can definitely be challenging to find a balance between work and school, especially when your work schedule is unpredictable. Maybe we can explore some strategies that allow for flexibility, so you can make the most of your study time without adding more stress. For example, have you considered setting aside a specific number of hours each week for studying, rather than specific times? That way, you can work around your changing schedule.

I've considered setting aside a specific number of hours each week for studying, but I'm worried it might not be enough to cover all my coursework without overlapping with my unpredictable work shifts. That flexibility sounds helpful, though, as long as I can ensure it doesn't lead to lastminute cramming and more burnout.

That's a valid concern! Balancing work and school can be tricky, and it's important to avoid lastminute cramming and burnout. Maybe we can think about ways to maximize the effectiveness of your study time, so you can make the most of those hours you set aside. Have you tried using any specific study techniques, like the Pomodoro Technique or the SQ3R method, that might help you stay focused and efficient?

I've tried the Pomodoro Technique a few times, but it's been hard to maintain with my erratic work schedule, often leading to incomplete sessions. The SQ3R method sounds useful for comprehension, though I'm concerned it might add more pressure if I can't dedicate enough uninterrupted time to it.

It's understandable that the Pomodoro Technique might be challenging with your unpredictable work schedule. The SQ3R method can be helpful, but you're right that it does require some uninterrupted time. Perhaps we can explore ways to make the most of the time you do have, by breaking down the SQ3R method into smaller steps that can be spread out over the course of a day or week. For example, you could focus on just the Survey and Question steps during short breaks at work, and then tackle the Read, Recite, and Review steps during your dedicated study hours.

I've tried breaking down study methods like that in the past, but it's tough to keep up with the SQ3R steps spread out due to my unpredictable shifts, which often leaves me feeling scattered and at risk of burnout. Still, focusing on shorter steps during breaks could be worth trying if it helps me stay on top of my coursework without overwhelming my already packed schedule.

It's great that you're open to trying new strategies, even when it's tough to maintain a consistent schedule. Remember, it's okay if things don't work out perfectly at firstthe key is to keep experimenting and adjusting until you find what works best for you. Have you considered reaching out to your professors or academic advisors for additional support or resources? They might have some helpful suggestions based on your specific situation.

I've thought about reaching out to my professors or academic advisors for support, but I haven't done it yet because I'm worried it might add more to my already overwhelming schedule. Still, I know getting their advice could help me manage my classes and work without risking further burnout.

It's natural to feel hesitant about adding more to your already busy schedule. But remember, your professors and advisors are there to support you, and they might have valuable insights or resources that can actually help you manage your workload more effectively. Maybe we can brainstorm some ways to make that initial outreach less overwhelming, like sending a brief email or setting up a short meeting during office hours.

I've been hesitant to reach out to professors or advisors because it feels like one more thing on my plate, but I'm open to brainstorming simple ways like sending a quick email to make it less daunting. That could help me manage my workload without adding to the stress I'm already feeling from juggling work and classes.

It's great that you're open to exploring ways to make reaching out to your professors or advisors feel less overwhelming. Here are a few ideas to get started

 Draft a brief email template that you can customize for each professor or advisor, explaining your situation and asking for their advice or resources.
 Set aside a small amount of time each week, like 30 minutes, to send out those emails or schedule short meetings during office hours.
 Remember, you don't have to tackle everything at onceeven just sending one email or scheduling one meeting can be a step in the right direction.

I've appreciate the email template idea, as it seems like a simple way to start reaching out without overwhelming myself further. Still, I'm concerned that even a little extra time for meetings might add to my packed schedule, but I know it could ultimately help me avoid burnout by getting better support for balancing work and classes.

That's a valid concern, and it's important to balance your time carefully. One strategy that might help is to prioritize the meetings that you think will be most helpful, and try to schedule them during times when you're less likely to have conflicts with work or classes. You could also consider asking if your professors or advisors are open to meeting virtually or over the phone, which could save you time and make it easier to fit into your schedule.

I've considered prioritizing and scheduling meetings for the most helpful professors, which could make outreach more manageable. However, I'm worried that even virtual options might add unexpected stress to my already tight schedule of work and classes.

You're doing a great job considering all the potential challenges. One thing to remember is that reaching out for support is an investment in your longterm success and wellbeing. While it might add some stress in the short term, it can ultimately help you find a more sustainable balance between work and school. And remember, you don't have to do everything at onceyou can start small and build from there.

I appreciate the reminder that starting small can lead to better longterm balance, and I'm willing to try sending just one email to begin with. Even so, I'm concerned that any added commitments might heighten my stress from juggling work and classes.
